Hi Joseph, 
We have many examples of cell phone policies and resources on BYOD policies on the Knowledge Network. Below I have listed a few of both that will hopefully help you begin developing a comprehensive cell phone and technology policy for your local government. 
BYOD Resources
-How to safely implement a BYOD policy is a recent ICMA publication http://bookstore.icma.org/product1.cfm?Product_ID=2378
-What's BYOD.... and why is might make you want to BYOB http://icma.org/en/BlogPost/1563/Whats_BYODand_Why_It_Might_Make_You_Want_to_BYOB
-Information Technology in Local Government http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/blogs/blog/69/Information_Technology_in_Local_Government
-Mobile Devices Bring Benefits but Raise Management Issues http://icma.org/en/BlogPost/1594/Mobile_Devices_Bring_Benefits_but_Raise_Management_Issues
General Cell Phone Policies
-This article includes all the best cell phone policy, purchasing, stipend, and general cell phone related resources on the Knowledge Network http://icma.org/en/Article/104286/Update_Your_Cell_Phone_Policy_with_These_Resources
Best, 
Robin Saywitz 
ICMA Knowledge Network Inetn
rsaywitz@icma.org

author: Joseph Gacioch
text:
The City of Ferndale is looking to develop a policy that considers modern and future mobile environments.  Historically, the City has not had a written staff cell phone use and renewal policy.  The City will likely consider a BYOD approach as city technology and telecommunication systems and foundations become more developed.  In short, the city needs to crawl before we can run.  
That being said, are other cities able to share a cell phone use and purchase/renewal policy that has been implemented and managed well throughout their organization?  
Thanks in advance for any sample policy or input you might provide!
title: City Mobile Phone Purchase and Use Policy
